comment: This is a curious move. It threatens Pe5 which forces White, at least for the moment, to leave Nf3, which blocks Pf2 from advancing. Also, it prevents Bc1-f4 and clears the way for Bf8 to develop. I suppose Black decides how to develop his king-side pieces depending upon where White develops Bc1. If b2-b3, Bc1-b2 then Bf8 probably has to remain in place for a while to defend Pg7.
reasoning: The comment effectively explains the potential consequences of the move and highlights the strategic considerations for the player.

reformulated: The move by Black is questionable. It puts pressure on White's pawn on e5, forcing them to leave their knight on f3, which then blocks the pawn on f2 from moving forward. Additionally, it opens up the path for the bishop on f1 to potentially develop. Black's strategy seems to hinge on White's decision about how they develop their bishop. If White moves their pawn from b2 to b3, then the bishop on c1 could jump to b2, requiring the bishop on f8 to stay put for some time to defend the pawn on g7.
